questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of fever and pain in the left ear for the past 3 days. The mother states that he has been rubbing his left ear repeatedly since he woke up this morning. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and his mother is concerned that the boy's ear pain may result from excessive scratching. She also notes that his latest flareup resolved several days before his birthday party, which he celebrated 1 week ago at a swimming pool. Six months ago, he had an episode of urticaria following antibiotic treatment for pharyngitis. He takes no medications. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Otoscopy shows an opaque, bulging tympanic membrane. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone and gentamicin eardrops can be used to treat otitis externa (OE), which typically manifests with ear pain, itching, and otorrhea and may be associated with water exposure (e.g., from swimming). However, OE manifests with tragal tenderness and a red edematous external auditory canal on otoscopy, neither of which is seen here. Topical antibiotic therapy is not effective for AOM because it cannot reach the middle ear.

B) CORRECT:

Most cases of AOM can be managed with symptomatic treatment and observation only, but systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated in children with symptoms persisting > 48 hours, bilateral AOM, otorrhea, and/or signs of severe illness (e.g., fever ≥ 39°C, vomiting, malaise). While amoxicillin is the first-line treatment option for AOM, it should be avoided in patients with a history of allergic reactions to penicillin and its derivatives. This patient likely has a penicillin allergy given his history of urticaria following a course of antibiotics for pharyngitis, for which penicillin derivatives are the first-line treatment. Macrolides like azithromycin are the recommended alternative treatment options for patients with AOM and penicillin allergy.

C) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion may be considered in patients with chronic otitis media or recurrent AOM (3 episodes in 6 months or 4 episodes in 1 year), neither of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.

1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

D) INCORRECT:

Otic ofloxacin is used to treat otitis externa (OE), which typically manifests with ear pain, itching, and otorrhea and may be associated with water exposure (e.g., swimming). However, OE also manifests with tragal tenderness and a red edematous external auditory canal on otoscopy, neither of which is seen here. Topical antibiotic therapy has no therapeutic benefit in patients with AOM, as it is unable to penetrate the tympanic membrane and reach the middle ear.

E) INCORRECT:

Tympanocentesis with Gram stain and culture of the middle ear fluid is indicated for patients with AOM who do not respond to initial therapy. This patient has not received treatment for AOM yet.

F) INCORRECT:

While amoxicillin-clavulanate can be used as a first-line treatment for AOM, it should be avoided in patients with a history of allergic reactions to penicillin derivatives. This patient likely has a penicillin allergy given his history of urticaria following a course of antibiotics for pharyngitis, for which penicillin derivatives are the first-line treatment.
questions.hint: This child presents with fever, ear pain, and ear rubbing, and he has an opaque, bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy, making acute otitis media (AOM) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of increased irritability, continual crying, and fever for 1 day. His mother has noticed that he refuses to lie down on his right side and keeps tugging at his right ear. One week ago, he had a runny nose that has since improved. He was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months of age and is currently bottle-fed with some solid foods introduced. He has been attending a daycare center for the past 5 months. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and pulse is 144/min. Otoscopic examination in this child is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Yellow mass behind the tympanic membrane
Brown mass within the ear canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Otoscopic examination in AOM typically shows a bulging erythematous tympanic membrane (TM) due to the accumulation of purulent secretions in the middle ear. Other common findings include TM opacification and loss of light reflex. AOM may cause rupture of the TM, which leads to purulent or serosanguinous otorrhea.

In otherwise healthy children aged > 6 months with uncomplicated, unilateral AOM, as seen here, pain relief and observation are the mainstays of treatment. Systemic antibiotic treatment should be considered if symptoms do not improve within 48–72 hours.

B) INCORRECT:

A retracted opacified tympanic membrane is a typical finding in otitis media with effusion (OME). OME is most common in toddlers and typically occurs after an episode of AOM. However, OME is usually painless and does not cause fever.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane (TM)

There is no noticeable bulging of the TM and the light reflex is visible in its normal position in the anterior inferior quadrant, indicating the TM is in a neutral position. The TMs yellow color and slight opacity suggest a serous effusion. There is no erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

An erythematous external auditory canal is seen in otitis externa (OE), which manifests with ear pain, fever, and possible “ear tugging” in a child (due to pruritus). However, this child does not have any risk factors that are typically associated with OE (i.e., injury to the skin of the external auditory canal and/or exposure to water). Moreover, the absence of otorrhea and auricular erythema/tenderness makes OE an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A yellow or white mass behind the tympanic membrane is consistent with congenital cholesteatoma. However, cholesteatoma manifests with foul-smelling otorrhea and does not cause ear pain or fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Vesicles in the ear canal can be seen in herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with ear pain, fever, and irritability. However, the vesicles typically also involve the outer ear and additional neurological features (e.g., vertigo, facial nerve paralysis) are expected. Furthermore, herpes zoster oticus is much less common than AOM.

F) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction would be seen as an irregular brown mass within the ear canal that can also cause ear discomfort in an infant, but it would not cause fever.

Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the external auditory canal

The auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.
questions.hint: Ear pain, often suggested by excessive crying and ear tugging, in combination with irritability, fever, and a recent upper respiratory infection (URI) is the classic presentation of acute otitis media (AOM) in infants. In this age group, bottle feeding, inadequate breastfeeding, and attending a daycare center are risk factors for AOM.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and irritability. The mother says he has been tugging on his left ear since yesterday evening. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and was exclusively breastfed until 3 months of age, when the parents introduced formula feeding. He is now eating some solid foods and receives one bottle of formula at night. He underwent cheiloplasty at 3 months of age because of an incomplete cleft lip. He and his two older siblings spend time together on weekdays when looked after by an au pair. He has been attending parent-child swimming classes for the past 2 months. His father smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily; his mother does not smoke. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination of the pharynx reveals pink tonsils. Otoscopy of the left ear shows erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks. Examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An incomplete cleft lip is a cleft on the upper lip that does not extend into the nostril. It can lead to suckling difficulties but does not increase the risk of AOM. A cleft palate, which is commonly associated with a complete cleft lip, is a risk factor for AOM.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent contact with water is a risk factor for the development of otitis externa. Otitis externa manifests with severe pain, but other features are also expected, such as otorrhea, intense itching in the external auditory canal (EAC), and redness and swelling of the EAC on otoscopy. This patient's presentation is more consistent with AOM, for which frequent exposure to water is not a known risk factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Preterm birth is a risk factor for many conditions (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, patent ductus arteriosus, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia), and there is some evidence that it may lead to a moderately increased risk of AOM. However, another factor more strongly predisposes this patient to developing AOM.

D) INCORRECT:

Formula feeding and associated lack of breastfeeding increase the risk for AOM most likely because of the lack of maternal antibodies as well as physical factors (e.g., feeding position, altered pharyngeal pressure) that lead to the pooling of milk in the eustachian tube. Although this patient has only been breastfed for three months, any duration of breastfeeding is more protective than no breastfeeding at all. Another factor more strongly predisposes this child to developing AOM.

E) CORRECT:

Passive tobacco exposure leads to an increased risk of AOM most likely because nicotine reduces the mucociliary clearance of the eustachian tube and increases the susceptibility of the mucosa of the middle ear to infection. The incidence of AOM in children peaks at 6–12 months of age, which might be related to a shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube and feeding in a supine position that allows nasal secretions to enter the middle ear cavity. Other risk factors include a family history of AOM, daycare attendance, lack of breastfeeding, pacifier use, and anatomical abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate).
questions.hint: Erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks on otoscopy suggests acute otitis media (AOM).

questions.text: A 20-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fever and pain in the right ear for the past 2 days. The mother says her daughter had three episodes of the same symptoms that resolved with antibiotics during the past year. The patient attends daycare 5 days per week and participates in parent-child swimming classes. She has no known medication allergies. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. On examination, she cries and tugs on her right ear. Otoscopy of the right ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane with an air-fluid level in the anterosuperior quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best approach to prevent the recurrence of these symptoms in this patient?

choices.text: Application of acetic acid ear drops after swimming

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure to repair a nonhealing defect in the tympanic membrane. This procedure is indicated to prevent recurrence in patients with chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) who do not respond to conservative measures. CSOM manifests with persistent drainage from the middle ear through a perforated tympanic membrane. This patient has no ear discharge or evidence of perforation on otoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

The application of acetic acid ear drops after swimming helps to dry and reacidify the ear canal and prevent skin maceration. This intervention is used to stop the recurrence of otitis externa, for which swimming is a risk factor. Although otitis externa manifests with severe pain, other features such as otorrhea, intense itching in the external auditory canal (EAC), and redness and swelling of the EAC on otoscopy would also be expected. This patient has AOM, which requires a different approach.

C) CORRECT:

Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion should be considered in children with recurrent AOM (i.e., ≥ 4 episodes in 12 months or ≥ 3 episodes in 6 months). The placement of small tubes in the tympanic membrane enables the drainage of fluid and helps to maintain an air-filled space in the middle ear, which can decrease the frequency of AOM episodes. The use of prophylactic antibiotics in recurrent AOM is not recommended.

Acute management of AOM, on the other hand, consists of analgesia (acetaminophen and/or ibuprofen). Antibiotic treatment (e.g., oral amoxicillin) is indicated in patients ≤ 6 months of age, in those < 2 years of age with bilateral AOM, and in all patients with severe infections (moderate to severe otalgia, otalgia lasting > 48 hours, and/or fever ≥ 39°C). Daycare attendance is a risk factor for AOM because of increased exposure to respiratory pathogens.
Image Description:

The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.

1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

D) INCORRECT:

Enlarged adenoids are a risk factor for mechanical obstruction of the eustachian tube, which can lead to AOM. Adenoidectomy can be used as a preventive measure in patients who develop AOM despite the presence of tympanostomy tubes. Although this patient most likely has recurrent AOM, otoscopy did not show tympanostomy tubes.

E) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotic treatment is not recommended to prevent recurrent AOM according to the American Academy of Pediatrics. Amoxicillin is the first-line antibiotic agent for treating antibiotic-naive patients with AOM. However, oral rather than topical administration is preferred, as topical antibiotics are generally ineffective.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, otalgia, and fluid accumulation behind an erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane (TM) on otoscopy indicates acute otitis media (AOM).

questions.text:
A 5-month-old girl has had fever and increased fussiness for the past 2 days, as well as rhinorrhea and nasal congestion for the past 4 days. Her father reports that she has been teething and that she was crying last night and had difficulty sleeping. She had an episode of acute otitis media 2 months ago. She has no chronic medical conditions and has never been hospitalized. She was a full-term infant, and her immunizations are up to date. She is formula-fed. Both parents smoke at home. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, the patient is fussy but appears well. Her temperature is 38.1°C, her heart rate is 126 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 86/52 mm Hg. She has clear nasal drainage.
The right tympanic membrane is noted to be opaque with surrounding erythema, and it appears to be bulging. No perforation or otorrhea is evident. There is a loss of normal landmarks and decreased movement with pneumatic otoscopy.
The left tympanic membrane is gray and translucent, with normal landmarks and movement.
In addition to managing symptoms with acetaminophen, what is the most appropriate next step for this infant?

choices.text: Recommend watchful waiting, and arrange for follow-up in 2 days to check for persistent otitis media
Consult with otolaryngology for placement of tympanostomy tubes
Recommend watchful waiting, and arrange for follow-up in 2 weeks to check for signs of chronic middle-ear effusion
Recommend an over-the-counter nasal decongestant spray

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For children older than 6 months who have unilateral AOM, mild symptoms, fever <39°C, and normal immune systems, a wait-and-see approach to antibiotic therapy should be discussed with parents as an option. If this approach is implemented, close follow-up should be arranged for 48 to 72 hours after initial diagnosis or a prescription for antibiotic therapy should be provided, but caregivers should initiate therapy only if symptoms persist or worsen (increased ear pain, temperature >39°C). Children with bilateral disease can be offered watchful waiting if they are at least 2 years of age, but those younger than 2 years should be treated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's history and physical examination indicate a diagnosis of right-sided acute otitis media (AOM). AOM is the most common condition for which antibiotics are prescribed in children. The judicious use of antibiotics is an important principle to follow.

For children younger than 6 months with AOM, the most appropriate care is prompt treatment with oral antibiotics and pain control with acetaminophen. The first-line treatment for AOM is high-dose amoxicillin, 90 mg/kg/day, divided twice daily. If the patient had a recent infection treated with antibiotics (within the past 30 days), amoxicillin-clavulanate would be appropriate given the risk for development of beta-lactam resistance.

Key learning point: For a child younger than 6 months with acute otitis media, the most appropriate care strategy is prompt initiation of oral antibiotics and a pain-control medication.

C) INCORRECT:

Tympanostomy tubes may be considered for a child who has any of the following:

• Frequent AOM episodes (defined as more than three episodes within 6 months or four episodes within one year) with evidence of middle-ear effusion at the time of evaluation
• Middle-ear effusion lasting >3 months
• Middle-ear effusion with speech delay, hearing difficulties, or both

D) INCORRECT:

Seventy percent of children with AOM have abnormalities on otoscopic examination 2 weeks after initial presentation, so follow-up in that time frame is not helpful. A more appropriate plan is for follow-up at 8 to 12 weeks after the initial AOM diagnosis, to ensure resolution of any middle-ear effusion, which can cause conductive hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Over-the-counter decongestants are not recommended for children younger than 2 years old, given the risk for adverse effects and a lack of evidence for symptom relief. Furthermore, topical nasal decongestants are not recommended for middle-ear pathology in infants.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl with no significant medical history has had rhinorrhea and nasal congestion for 4 days, as well as one day of fever and left-ear pain.
Her current temperature is 38°C, and her other vital signs are within normal limits for her age. She appears tired. She has mild bilateral conjunctival injection and clear rhinorrhea.
Visual otoscopy is performed (figure). Pneumatic otoscopy demonstrates impaired mobility of the tympanic membrane.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholesteatoma is an accumulation of squamous epithelial cells, usually visible as a discrete white mass behind the TM. It can be congenital or acquired, most commonly in the setting of chronic otitis media.

B) INCORRECT:

Otitis media with effusion (OME) can be defined as effusion within the middle ear without evidence of infection. OME and AOM can both overlap with upper respiratory viral infections, and fever can be a presenting symptom in either condition, but one would not expect otalgia with OME. Fluid is present behind the TM in either condition, but in OME, the fluid is less likely to be opaque, and the TM is less likely to be bulging and is not erythematous.

C) INCORRECT:

Bullous myringitis is a manifestation of AOM in which bullae are present on the TM; however, no bullae are visible in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s tympanic membrane (TM) is bulging, opaque, and injected, with impaired mobility. This constellation of findings makes acute otitis media (AOM) the most likely diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a child with fever and ear pain who has a bulging, opaque, erythematous tympanic membrane with impaired mobility is acute otitis media.

E) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the TM can occur as a complication of AOM, but this patient has no apparent defect in the TM.

questions.text:
A mother brings her 18-month-old daughter to the emergency department because the girl is unable to sleep. She attends day care and has had persistent nasal congestion for the past 2 months. During the past 24 hours, she has developed a new cough and a fever, with a temperature of 39.5°C. She is extremely fussy and not eating well.
On examination, her temperature is 38.9°C, her heart rate is 128 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 88/43 mm Hg. There is substantial nasal congestion and a thick nasal discharge.
Her left tympanic membrane is intact but erythematous and moderately bulging; her right tympanic membrane appears normal.
In addition to pain relief, what is the best next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Distinguishing acute otitis media (AOM) from otitis media with effusion (OME) may be challenging because the two conditions represent ends of a disease continuum. The distinction, however, is important because AOM may require antibiotic therapy. In contrast, OME does not require antibiotics, only monitoring for resolution, particularly if a child has hearing and speech concerns.

Moderate-to-severe bulging of the tympanic membrane is the most important characteristic for diagnosing AOM. In addition, the tympanic membrane often appears cloudy, with impaired mobility.

The bulging, erythematous appearance of this child's tympanic membrane suggests a diagnosis of unilateral AOM. Given that she has had a fever >39°C, antibiotics are required. First-line therapy consists of a 10-day course of high-dose amoxicillin (90 mg/kg/day divided into two doses per day) because Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial cause.

Key learning point: The clinical finding most suggestive of acute otitis media is that the tympanic membrane appears bulging.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat recurrent AOM but is not a first-line therapy because it is a more broad-spectrum antibiotic than amoxicillin, and it is more challenging to administer. In recurrent AOM, three doses of intramuscular ceftriaxone have been shown to be superior to one for eradicating penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae from the middle ear.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is not recommended for treatment of AOM unless the child has a well-documented amoxicillin allergy.

D) INCORRECT:

For children older than 6 months who have unilateral AOM, mild symptoms, fever <39°C, and normal immune systems, a wait-and-see approach to antibiotic therapy should be discussed with parents as an option. If this approach is implemented, close follow-up should be arranged for 48 to 72 hours after initial diagnosis or a prescription for antibiotic therapy should be provided, but caregivers should initiate therapy only if symptoms persist or worsen (increased ear pain, temperature >39°C). Children with bilateral disease can be offered watchful waiting if they are at least 2 years of age, but those younger than 2 years should be treated.

E) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is not considered first-line therapy for uncomplicated AOM. It should be reserved for infections not responding to amoxicillin and can be considered in children with more complicated cases, such as those with multiple prior infections or AOM with acute tympanic membrane perforation.

questions.text:
A previously well 11-month-old girl is evaluated for a one-day history of fever that has been as high as 38.9°C. The clinical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of bilateral otitis media.
In addition to antibiotic management of the otitis media, what is the most appropriate strategy for managing this patient's fever?

choices.text: Acetaminophen given by mouth every 4 hours around the clock
Acetaminophen given by mouth up to every 4 to 6 hours as needed
Ibuprofen alternating with acetaminophen given by mouth every 4 hours around the clock
Ibuprofen given by mouth up to every 4 hours as needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Giving antipyretic medications at standing intervals around the clock is unnecessary and can lead to overtreatment. Acetaminophen should be given up to every 4 to 6 hours as needed.

B) CORRECT:

The best strategy for managing fever in children is to instruct the parents to give appropriately dosed antipyretics as needed, in order to improve the patient’s comfort and potentially to reduce insensible water losses. Although many parents believe that a fever itself is dangerous and must be controlled in order to prevent seizures or brain damage, this belief is not supported by the literature, and fever can, in fact, be a beneficial aspect of the body’s response to infection.

Acetaminophen can be given to both infants and children and should be dosed at 15 mg/kg. The maximum recommended dose is 75 mg/kg/day for infants and 100 mg/kg/day for older children. Ibuprofen may only be used in children older than 6 months and should be dosed at 10 mg/kg.

Acetaminophen and ibuprofen are both suitable options for this child, given that she is older than 6 months.

Key learning point: The appropriate strategy for managing fever in a child with otitis media is a properly dosed antipyretic, given as needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Tepid water and alcohol baths do not necessarily provide comfort, even if they reduce body temperature, and alcohol baths have been reported to lead to systemic alcohol absorption.

D) INCORRECT:

Alternating the two medications at regular intervals is not appropriate because it can lead to overtreatment and dosing errors. Ibuprofen is dosed every 6 to 8 hours as needed, not every 4 hours, and acetaminophen should be given up to every 4 to 6 hours as needed.

E) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen may only be used in children older than 6 months and should be dosed at 10 mg/kg. Ibuprofen is dosed every 6 to 8 hours as needed, not every 4 hours.

questions.text:
A previously healthy, 20-month-old boy presents with his mother, who reports yellow drainage from his left ear. He was well until 5 days ago, when he developed symptoms of an upper respiratory infection. Three days ago, he began to pull on his left ear and developed a fever to 38.9°C and increased fussiness. This morning, the mother noted drainage from the ear.
On physical examination, the child is mildly fussy and afebrile. Purulent discharge is noted on examination of the left auditory canal, with a small hole visible in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, which is erythematous.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Start oral amoxicillin 80 to 90 mg/kg/day for 10 days
Advise symptomatic care with a return visit in 48 hours
Refer to otolaryngology for surgical intervention
Recommend aural lavage with a sterile saline solution

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A small, spontaneous rupture of the tympanic membrane in the anterior-inferior quadrant is considered to be a mild complication of otitis media. High-dose oral amoxicillin (80–90 mg/kg/day, given in two divided doses) is the first-line treatment, aimed at addressing the acute otitis media. Small ruptures of the tympanic membrane typically resolve without surgical intervention.

Key learning point: Small, spontaneous ruptures of the tympanic membrane in the setting of acute otitis media require no treatment other than treatment for the otitis media.

B) INCORRECT:

Otic drops containing neomycin should not be used in the setting of spontaneous tympanic-membrane rupture, as neomycin is highly ototoxic.

C) INCORRECT:

Although most recommendations for treating otitis media in children >2 years old include a watchful-waiting option, there is general consensus that children <2 years old and those with otorrhea should receive prompt antibiotic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Small ruptures of the tympanic membrane typically resolve without surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Aural lavage should also be avoided in cases of spontaneous rupture of the tympanic membrane. When a perforation occurs, efforts should be made to keep the ear dry, as water or irrigation exposure can potentially exacerbate the infected middle-ear mucosa.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the office because of increased irritability, continual crying, and fever for 1 day. His mother has noticed that he refuses to lie down on his right side and keeps tugging at his right ear. One week ago, he had a runny nose that has since improved. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months of age and is currently bottle-fed with some solid foods introduced. He has been attending a daycare center for the past 5 months. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Otoscopic examination in this child is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Yellow mass behind the tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Otoscopic examination in AOM typically shows a bulging erythematous tympanic membrane (TM) due to the accumulation of purulent secretions in the middle ear. Other common findings include TM opacification and loss of light reflex. AOM may cause rupture of the TM, which leads to purulent or serosanguinous otorrhea.

In otherwise healthy children aged > 6 months with uncomplicated, unilateral AOM, as seen here, pain relief and observation are the mainstays of treatment. Systemic antibiotic treatment should be considered if symptoms do not improve within 48–72 hours.

Key learning point: Acute otitis media is characterized by a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination due to purulent middle ear effusion.

B) INCORRECT:

A retracted opacified tympanic membrane is a typical finding in otitis media with effusion (OME). OME is most common in toddlers and typically occurs after an episode of AOM. However, OME is usually painless and does not cause fever.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane (TM)

There is no noticeable bulging of the TM and the light reflex is visible in its normal position in the anterior inferior quadrant, indicating the TM is in a neutral position. The TMs yellow color and slight opacity suggest a serous effusion. There is no erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

An erythematous external auditory canal is seen in otitis externa (OE), which manifests with ear pain, fever, and possible “ear tugging” in a child (due to pruritus). However, this child does not have any risk factors that are typically associated with OE (i.e., injury to the skin of the external auditory canal and/or exposure to water). Moreover, the absence of otorrhea and auricular erythema/tenderness makes OE an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A yellow or white mass behind the tympanic membrane is consistent with congenital cholesteatoma. However, cholesteatoma manifests with foul-smelling otorrhea and does not cause ear pain or fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Vesicles in the ear canal can be seen in herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with ear pain, fever, and irritability. However, the vesicles typically also involve the outer ear and additional neurological features (e.g., vertigo, facial nerve paralysis) are expected. Furthermore, herpes zoster oticus is much less common than AOM.
questions.hint: Ear pain, often suggested by excessive crying and ear tugging, in combination with irritability, fever, and a recent upper respiratory infection (URI) is the classic presentation of acute otitis media (AOM) in infants. In this age group, bottle feeding, inadequate breastfeeding, and attending a daycare center are risk factors for AOM.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and irritability. The mother says he has been tugging on his left ear since yesterday evening. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and exclusively breastfed until 3 months of age, when the parents introduced formula feeding. He underwent cheiloplasty at 3 months of age because of an incomplete cleft lip. He has been attending parent-child swimming classes for the past 2 months. His father smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily. Otoscopy of the left ear shows erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An incomplete cleft lip is a cleft on the upper lip that does not extend into the nostril. It can lead to suckling difficulties but does not increase the risk of AOM. A cleft palate, which is commonly associated with a complete cleft lip, is a risk factor for AOM.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent contact with water is a risk factor for the development of otitis externa. Otitis externa manifests with severe pain, but other features are also expected, such as otorrhea, intense itching in the external auditory canal (EAC), and redness and swelling of the EAC on otoscopy. This patient's presentation is more consistent with AOM, for which frequent exposure to water is not a known risk factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Preterm birth is a risk factor for many conditions (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, patent ductus arteriosus, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia), and there is some evidence that it may lead to a moderately increased risk of AOM. However, another factor more strongly predisposes this patient to developing AOM.

D) INCORRECT:

Formula feeding and associated lack of breastfeeding increase the risk for AOM most likely because of the lack of maternal antibodies as well as physical factors (e.g., feeding position, altered pharyngeal pressure) that lead to the pooling of milk in the eustachian tube. Although this patient has only been breastfed for three months, any duration of breastfeeding is more protective than no breastfeeding at all. Another factor more strongly predisposes this child to developing AOM.

E) CORRECT:

Passive tobacco exposure leads to an increased risk of AOM most likely because nicotine reduces the mucociliary clearance of the eustachian tube and increases the susceptibility of the mucosa of the middle ear to infection. The incidence of AOM in children peaks at 6–12 months of age, which might be related to a shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube and feeding in a supine position that allows nasal secretions to enter the middle ear cavity. Other risk factors include a family history of AOM, daycare attendance, lack of breastfeeding, pacifier use, and anatomical abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate).
questions.hint: Erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks on otoscopy suggests acute otitis media (AOM).

questions.text: A previously healthy, 20-month-old boy presents with his mother, who reports yellow drainage from his left ear. He was well until 5 days ago, when he developed symptoms of an upper respiratory infection. Three days ago, he began to pull on his left ear and developed a fever to 38.9°C (102.0°F). Purulent discharge is noted on examination of the left auditory canal, with a small hole visible in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, which is erythematous. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Symptomatic care and follow-up visit in 48 hours
Aural lavage with a sterile saline solution

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A small, spontaneous rupture of the tympanic membrane in the anterior-inferior quadrant is considered to be a mild complication of otitis media. High-dose oral amoxicillin (80–90 mg/kg/day, given in two divided doses) is the first-line treatment, aimed at addressing the acute otitis media. Small ruptures of the tympanic membrane typically resolve without surgical intervention.

Key learning point: Small, spontaneous ruptures of the tympanic membrane in the setting of acute otitis media require no treatment other than treatment for the otitis media.

B) INCORRECT:

Otic drops containing neomycin should not be used in the setting of spontaneous tympanic-membrane rupture, as neomycin is highly ototoxic.

C) INCORRECT:

Although most recommendations for treating otitis media in children >2 years old include a watchful-waiting option, there is general consensus that children <2 years old and those with otorrhea should receive prompt antibiotic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Small ruptures of the tympanic membrane typically resolve without surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Aural lavage should be avoided in cases of spontaneous rupture of the tympanic membrane. When a perforation occurs, efforts should be made to keep the ear dry, as water or irrigation exposure can potentially exacerbate the infected middle-ear mucosa.

questions.text:
An 11-month-old child is brought to the clinic by parents with a 3-day history of irritability and decreased feeding. The child has had a fever of 39°C for the past 24 hours, and the mother notes episodes of tugging at the right ear. Physical examination shows moderate distress, erythema, and bulging of the right tympanic membrane with a small amount of yellowish fluid in the external canal. No other abnormalities are found on exam.

Temperature
39°C

Which of the following diagnoses best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute otitis media manifests with inflammation and infection of the middle ear, presenting with rapid onset of symptoms such as fever and irritability. In young children, the Eustachian tube's shorter and more horizontal anatomy predisposes them to this condition, facilitating bacterial ascent after upper respiratory infections. Clinically, ear pain is often inferred from behaviors like ear tugging, and systemic signs include high fever. Otoscopic examination reveals a red, bulging tympanic membrane and yellowish fluid, indicating purulent material accumulation behind the eardrum. These findings align with the characteristic presentation of acute otitis media.

Key learning point: Acute otitis media in infants is characterized by rapid onset of symptoms such as fever, irritability, and ear pain, and may lead to tympanic membrane perforation with pus discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

Otitis externa involves infection of the external auditory canal, with pain elicited by pinna or tragus manipulation and often linked to water exposure. The bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane and systemic symptoms, such as fever, suggest middle ear involvement rather than an isolated external canal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Serous otitis media, or otitis media with effusion, involves non-purulent, clear middle ear fluid without significant inflammation. The erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane and yellowish fluid indicate an active inflammatory process, inconsistent with the typically asymptomatic nature of serous otitis media.

D) INCORRECT:

Mastoiditis, a complication of middle ear infections, involves mastoid air cell inflammation, presenting with postauricular erythema, tenderness, and swelling. The absence of these findings, along with the presence of a bulging tympanic membrane, supports a diagnosis of acute otitis media rather than mastoiditis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to inconsolable crying and tugging at his left ear for the past day. He refuses to eat and appears quite fussy. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with fluid visible behind it. The external ear canal is not tender and has no discharge. The right ear is normal.

Temperature
38.9°C

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute otitis media manifests in children with rapid onset of ear pain, fever, and irritability. The 3-year-old's inconsolable crying, ear tugging, and refusal to eat indicate discomfort typical of this condition. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with middle ear effusion, pathognomonic for acute otitis media. These findings, along with a fever of 38.9°C, suggest inflammation and fluid accumulation in the middle ear due to infection.

Key learning point: Acute otitis media is characterized by fever, irritability, and a bulging tympanic membrane with air-fluid levels, distinguishing it from otitis externa and chronic ear conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Otitis externa, or 'swimmer's ear', involves infection of the external auditory canal, presenting with pain on pinna manipulation, canal erythema, and discharge. The absence of external canal tenderness and the presence of a bulging tympanic membrane with middle ear effusion indicate a middle ear pathology, not otitis externa.

C) INCORRECT:

Serous otitis media involves nonpurulent fluid behind the tympanic membrane, typically without acute inflammation. The bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane and systemic symptoms in this child suggest an acute infectious process, not the indolent course of serous otitis media.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic suppurative otitis media involves persistent tympanic membrane perforation and chronic ear discharge. The acute presentation with a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane and no perforation or chronic discharge distinguishes this case from chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy presents with fussiness, ear pulling, and low-grade fever. Otoscopy reveals a red, bulging tympanic membrane. Which organism is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Group A Streptococcus is primarily associated with pharyngitis and skin infections. It is not a common cause of acute otitis media, which is typically due to nasopharyngeal pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is more commonly associated with skin and soft tissue infections. It can cause otologic infections in cases of tympanic membrane perforation or chronic suppurative otitis media, but it is not a typical cause of uncomplicated acute otitis media in young children.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is commonly linked to otitis externa, especially in swimmers, but is rarely a cause of acute otitis media in children. The typical pathogens for acute otitis media include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

D) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the leading cause of acute otitis media in children. It colonizes the nasopharynx and can ascend to the middle ear, especially after a viral upper respiratory infection. The symptoms of fussiness, ear pulling, and low-grade fever, along with a red, bulging tympanic membrane, are indicative of this bacterial infection. Understanding the link between nasopharyngeal colonization and middle ear infection is essential for diagnosis and prevention, including pneumococcal vaccination.

Key learning point: Bacterial pathogens, particularly Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis, are the most common causes of acute otitis media in children.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-month-old boy who is brought to your clinic because of increased irritability, persistent crying, and fever for 1 day. His mother reports that he refuses to lie on his right side and frequently tugs at his right ear. He had a runny nose one week ago, which has since resolved. He was exclusively breastfed until 2 months of age and is now bottle-fed with some solid foods introduced. He has attended daycare for the past 5 months. His temperature is 38.4°C. On otoscopic examination, which one of the following findings is most likely?

choices.text: Yellow mass behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vesicles in the ear canal can be seen in herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with ear pain, fever, and irritability. However, the vesicles typically also involve the outer ear and additional neurological features (e.g., vertigo, facial nerve paralysis) are expected. Furthermore, herpes zoster oticus is much less common than AOM.

B) INCORRECT:

A retracted opacified tympanic membrane is a typical finding in otitis media with effusion (OME). OME is most common in toddlers and typically occurs after an episode of AOM. However, OME is usually painless and does not cause fever.

C) CORRECT:

Otoscopic examination in AOM typically shows a bulging erythematous tympanic membrane (TM) due to the accumulation of purulent secretions in the middle ear. Other common findings include TM opacification and loss of light reflex. AOM may cause rupture of the TM, which leads to purulent or serosanguinous otorrhea.

In otherwise healthy children aged > 6 months with uncomplicated, unilateral AOM, as seen here, pain relief and observation are the mainstays of treatment. Systemic antibiotic treatment should be considered if symptoms do not improve within 48–72 hours.

Key learning point: Acute otitis media is characterized by a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination due to purulent middle ear effusion.

D) INCORRECT:

A yellow or white mass behind the tympanic membrane is consistent with congenital cholesteatoma. However, cholesteatoma manifests with foul-smelling otorrhea and does not cause ear pain or fever.

E) INCORRECT:

An erythematous external auditory canal is seen in otitis externa (OE), which manifests with ear pain, fever, and possible “ear tugging” in a child (due to pruritus). However, this child does not have any risk factors that are typically associated with OE (i.e., injury to the skin of the external auditory canal and/or exposure to water). Moreover, the absence of otorrhea and auricular erythema/tenderness makes OE an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: Ear pain, often suggested by excessive crying and ear tugging, in combination with irritability, fever, and a recent upper respiratory infection (URI) is the classic presentation of acute otitis media (AOM) in infants. In this age group, bottle feeding, inadequate breastfeeding, and attending a daycare center are risk factors for AOM.

questions.text: You are seeing a 10-month-old boy brought to your clinic by his mother due to a 2-day history of fever and irritability. His mother reports that he has been tugging on his left ear since yesterday evening. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and was exclusively breastfed until 3 months of age, after which formula feeding was introduced. He underwent cheiloplasty at 3 months of age for an incomplete cleft lip. For the past 2 months, he has been attending parent-child swimming classes. His father smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. Otoscopy of the left ear reveals an erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks. Which one of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Formula feeding and associated lack of breastfeeding increase the risk for AOM most likely because of the lack of maternal antibodies as well as physical factors (e.g., feeding position, altered pharyngeal pressure) that lead to the pooling of milk in the eustachian tube. Although this patient has only been breastfed for three months, any duration of breastfeeding is more protective than no breastfeeding at all. Another factor more strongly predisposes this child to developing AOM.

B) CORRECT:

Passive tobacco exposure leads to an increased risk of AOM most likely because nicotine reduces the mucociliary clearance of the eustachian tube and increases the susceptibility of the mucosa of the middle ear to infection. The incidence of AOM in children peaks at 6–12 months of age, which might be related to a shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube and feeding in a supine position that allows nasal secretions to enter the middle ear cavity. Other risk factors include a family history of AOM, daycare attendance, lack of breastfeeding, pacifier use, and anatomical abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate).

Key learning point: Passive tobacco exposure is the strongest modifiable risk factor for acute otitis media in young children due to its detrimental effects on eustachian tube function and mucosal immunity.

C) INCORRECT:

Preterm birth is a risk factor for many conditions (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, patent ductus arteriosus, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia), and there is some evidence that it may lead to a moderately increased risk of AOM. However, another factor more strongly predisposes this patient to developing AOM.

D) INCORRECT:

An incomplete cleft lip is a cleft on the upper lip that does not extend into the nostril. It can lead to suckling difficulties but does not increase the risk of AOM. A cleft palate, which is commonly associated with a complete cleft lip, is a risk factor for AOM.

E) INCORRECT:

Frequent contact with water is a risk factor for the development of otitis externa. Otitis externa manifests with severe pain, but other features are also expected, such as otorrhea, intense itching in the external auditory canal (EAC), and redness and swelling of the EAC on otoscopy. This patient's presentation is more consistent with AOM, for which frequent exposure to water is not a known risk factor.
questions.hint: Erythematous and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks on otoscopy suggests acute otitis media (AOM).

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 20-month-old boy brought to your clinic by his mother because of yellow drainage from his left ear. Five days ago, he developed symptoms of an upper respiratory infection. Three days ago, he began pulling on his left ear and developed a fever to 38.9°C. On examination, there is purulent discharge in the left auditory canal and a small hole is visible in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the erythematous tympanic membrane. Which one of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?

choices.text: Symptomatic care and follow-up visit in 48 hours.
Aural lavage with a sterile saline solution.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A small, spontaneous rupture of the tympanic membrane in the anterior-inferior quadrant is considered to be a mild complication of otitis media. High-dose oral amoxicillin (80–90 mg/kg/day, given in two divided doses) is the first-line treatment, aimed at addressing the acute otitis media. Small ruptures of the tympanic membrane typically resolve without surgical intervention.

Key learning point: Small, spontaneous ruptures of the tympanic membrane in the setting of acute otitis media require no treatment other than treatment for the otitis media.

B) INCORRECT:

Although most recommendations for treating otitis media in children >2 years old include a watchful-waiting option, there is general consensus that children <2 years old and those with otorrhea should receive prompt antibiotic treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Otic drops containing neomycin should not be used in the setting of spontaneous tympanic-membrane rupture, as neomycin is highly ototoxic.

D) INCORRECT:

Aural lavage should be avoided in cases of spontaneous rupture of the tympanic membrane. When a perforation occurs, efforts should be made to keep the ear dry, as water or irrigation exposure can potentially exacerbate the infected middle-ear mucosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Small ruptures of the tympanic membrane typically resolve without surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of irritability, fever to 38.5°C (101.3°F), and decreased oral intake. He is otherwise healthy, does not take regular medication, and has no known allergies. His mother reports that he has been repeatedly touching his right ear and crying inconsolably. Otoscopic examination is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy is not routinely indicated as initial management for uncomplicated acute otitis media.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is not recommended as first-line therapy for acute otitis media, except in patients with a penicillin allergy, due to the high prevalence of macrolide resistance among common causative pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation with analgesics is appropriate for children aged 6–23 months with unilateral acute otitis media if symptoms are not severe. This patient's inconsolable crying suggests severe otalgia.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical ciprofloxacin is used for otitis externa or chronic suppurative otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation. Topical antibiotics cannot penetrate the tympanic membrane to reach the middle ear space in acute otitis media with an intact tympanic membrane.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets diagnostic criteria for acute otitis media with new-onset otalgia (evidenced by ear touching and crying) and mild bulging of the tympanic membrane with erythema. In children under 2 years of age, antibiotic therapy is recommended unless symptoms are mild. Amoxicillin is the first-line antibiotic choice for uncomplicated cases in children without recent antibiotic exposure.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the ED with worsening left ear pain and fever that began 2 days ago. The child was treated with amoxicillin for acute otitis media (AOM) 10 days ago and initially improved. On examination, the child appears ill. Vital signs are T, 39.1°C (102.4°F); P, 130; BP, 95/60. The external ear and surrounding area is shown.  Which finding is most consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- A tender and edematous mastoid process is the most characteristic finding of mastoiditis. Combined with ear displacement, postauricular swelling, and obliteration of the retroauricular sulcus, this finding confirms the diagnosis. The pathophysiology of mastoiditis involves infection spreading from the middle ear into the mastoid air cells, creating a collection of pus under tension.

B) INCORRECT:

Horizontal nystagmus with vertigo is characteristic of bacterial labyrinthitis. This condition involves the inner ear and causes severe vertigo but does not produce the postauricular findings seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A bulging and erythematous tympanic membrane is characteristic of AOM but may sometimes have a normal appearance in this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

A perforated tympanic membrane with otorrhea can occur with both simple AOM and in complications of AOM, but it is not a specific finding and may be absent in this patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Facial nerve palsy can occur as a complication of both AOM and this patient's condition, but it is not a routine finding.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of right ear pain and fever that initially improved with amoxicillin. This morning, he developed severe nausea, vomiting, and unsteady gait. Examination shows a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), bulging erythematous right tympanic membrane, and horizontal nystagmus. Weber test lateralizes to the left ear. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the temporal bone
Intravenous antibiotics and tympanostomy tube insertion
MRI of the brain with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the temporal bone is used to evaluate for mastoiditis if there is clinical suspicion based on retroauricular tenderness, swelling, or ear displacement. This patient's severe vertigo, nystagmus, and sensorineural hearing loss indicate inner ear involvement rather than mastoid pathology.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has bacterial labyrinthitis, indicated by severe vertigo, nystagmus, and Weber test change from affected to healthy ear (conductive to sensorineural hearing loss). Treatment requires IV antibiotics to address the infection and tympanostomy tube insertion to facilitate drainage from the middle ear source.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI with contrast is used to evaluate for intracranial complications such as brain abscess, which manifests with persistent headache, signs of increased intracranial pressure, and focal neurological deficits. This patient's symptoms are consistent with peripheral labyrinthine involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is indicated if there are signs of meningitis, such as neck stiffness, altered mental status, or other meningeal signs. This patient's constellation of symptoms specifically points to inner ear involvement rather than central nervous system infection.

E) INCORRECT:

While corticosteroids may be used as adjunctive therapy in labyrinthitis, oral prednisone alone without antibiotics is inadequate for treating this patient's infection, which requires immediate antibiotic therapy and surgical drainage.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with 3 days of fever and irritability. The child's temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), and external examination is shown. Otoscopy shows a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with purulent otorrhea. The child appears irritable but consolable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical ciprofloxacin drops are reserved for patients with tympanostomy tubes or chronic suppurative otitis media. This patient's condition requires systemic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy may be considered as an adjunct procedure for this patient, but the priority is initiating systemic antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not an appropriate therapy for this patient's condition as they do not treat the underlying infection.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of posterior auricular erythema, edema, anterior auricle displacement, and obliterated retroauricular sulcus indicates acute mastoiditis. This requires immediate intravenous antibiotics such as ceftriaxone. ENT consultation should also be obtained for admission and potential surgical intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is insufficient for this patient's condition. The clinical findings indicate extension beyond simple acute otitis media and require intravenous antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a 2-day history of irritability, poor feeding, and pulling at his right ear. For the past 24 hours, he has also had purulent discharge from both eyes. He has no known drug allergies. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Physical examination shows a bulging, erythematous right tympanic membrane with obscured landmarks. The left tympanic membrane is normal. Bilateral conjunctival injection with purulent exudate is also noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has acute otitis media with concurrent purulent conjunctivitis, a presentation known as otitis-conjunctivitis syndrome. This syndrome is most commonly caused by nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae, a significant portion of which produce beta-lactamase, rendering amoxicillin ineffective. Therefore, the first-line treatment is amoxicillin-clavulanate. The clavulanate component is a beta-lactamase inhibitor that restores amoxicillin's efficacy against these resistant organisms. This single systemic agent effectively treats both the middle ear infection and the associated conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotic drops are an appropriate treatment for isolated bacterial conjunctivitis. However, this patient also has acute otitis media, a systemic infection that requires systemic antibiotic therapy. Treating the conjunctivitis alone would leave the middle ear infection unaddressed. The conjunctivitis in this syndrome typically resolves with appropriate systemic antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that may be considered for acute otitis media in patients with a severe, type I hypersensitivity to penicillin. However, it is not a first-line agent due to significant resistance rates among common pathogens like Streptococcus pneumoniae. This patient has no known drug allergies, making a beta-lactam antibiotic preferable.

D) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is an effective treatment for acute otitis media but is generally reserved for patients who are unable to tolerate oral medications due to vomiting or for those for whom initial oral antibiotic therapy has been unsuccessful. Because this patient is presenting for initial treatment and can presumably take oral medication, this is not the most appropriate first step.

E) INCORRECT:

High-dose oral amoxicillin is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated acute otitis media in children who have not recently taken antibiotics. However, the presence of concurrent purulent conjunctivitis makes infection with a beta-lactamase-producing organism, such as nontypeable H. influenzae, highly likely. Amoxicillin alone would not be effective against such a pathogen.
questions.hint: Acute otitis media with purulent conjunctivitis, known as otitis-conjunctivitis syndrome, is most commonly caused by a pathogen that frequently produces beta-lactamase.
